                                    BIBLIOGRAPHIC CITATION                      
0                                                                               
                 PUBLICATIONS   BASED  ON   ICPSR   DATA  COLLECTIONS  SHOULD   
                 ACKNOWLEDGE  THOSE   SOURCES   BY  MEANS  OF   BIBLIOGRAPHIC   
                 CITATIONS.  TO  ENSURE  THAT  SUCH  SOURCE  ATTRIBUTIONS ARE   
                 CAPTURED  FOR  SOCIAL   SCIENCE   BIBLIOGRAPHIC   UTILITIES,   
                 CITATIONS  MUST  APPEAR IN  FOOTNOTES  OR  IN THE  REFERENCE   
                 SECTION OF PUBLICATIONS. THE BIBLIOGRAPHIC CITATION FOR THIS   
                 DATA COLLECTION IS:                                            
0                                                                               
                       REIF, KARLHEINZ, AND ANNA MELICH.  EURO-BAROMETER 30:    
                       IMMIGRANTS AND OUT-GROUPS IN WESTERN EUROPE, OCTOBER-    
                       NOVEMBER 1988 [COMPUTER FILE].  CONDUCTED BY FAITS ET    
                       OPINIONS,   PARIS.   2ND  ICPSR ED.   ANN  ARBOR  MI:    
                       INTER-UNIVERSITY  CONSORTIUM FOR POLITICAL AND SOCIAL    
                       RESEARCH [PRODUCER AND DISTRIBUTOR], 1992.               
-                                                                               
                       REQUEST FOR INFORMATION ON USE OF ICPSR RESOURCES        
                                                                                
                 TO PROVIDE FUNDING AGENCIES WITH ESSENTIAL INFORMATION ABOUT   
                 USE OF ARCHIVAL  RESOURCES AND TO FACILITATE THE EXCHANGE OF   
                 INFORMATION ABOUT ICPSR  PARTICIPANTS'  RESEARCH ACTIVITIES,   
                 USERS  OF  ICPSR  DATA  ARE  REQUESTED  TO  SEND  TO   ICPSR   
                 BIBLIOGRAPHIC  CITATIONS  FOR  EACH  COMPLETED MANUSCRIPT OR   
                 THESIS ABSTRACT.  PLEASE  INDICATE  IN A COVER  LETTER WHICH   
                 DATA WERE USED.

                 COLLECTION OR FOR INTERPRETATIONS  OR INFERENCES BASED UPON    
                 SUCH USES.

                                               I                                
0                                                                               
                               THE EURO-BAROMETER SURVEY SERIES                 
0                                                                               
                 THE EURO-BAROMETER SURVEYS ARE THE FRUIT OF A UNIQUE PROGRAM   
                 OF CROSS-NATIONAL AND CROSS-TEMPORAL SOCIAL SCIENCE            
                 RESEARCH. THE EFFORT BEGAN IN EARLY 1970, WHEN THE             
                 COMMISSION OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES BEGAN TO CARRY OUT      
                 SIMULTANEOUS SURVEYS OF THE MEMBER NATIONS OF THE EUROPEAN     
                 COMMUNITY. EARLY EFFORTS CONTINUED WITH TWO MORE SURVEYS OF    
                 THE MEMBER NATIONS IN 1971 AND 1973. IN 1974, THE COMMISSION   
                 OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES OFFICIALLY LAUNCHED THE BIANNUAL   
                 EURO-BAROMETER SERIES OF SURVEYS, CONDUCTED IN THE SPRING      
                 AND FALL OF EACH YEAR. THESE SURVEYS ARE DESIGNED TO PROVIDE   
                 REGULAR MONITORING OF THE SOCIAL AND POLITICAL ATTITUDES OF    
                 THE PUBLICS IN THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY MEMBER NATIONS, NOW      
                 TWELVE IN NUMBER. OF PRIMARY CONCERN ARE PUBLIC AWARENESS      
                 OF, AND ATTITUDES TOWARD THE COMMON MARKET AND OTHER           
                 EUROPEAN COMMUNITY INSTITUTIONS AND POLICIES. SPECIAL TOPICS   
                 OF INTEREST, SUCH AS CONSUMER ATTITUDES, THE ENVIRONMENT,      
                 GENDER ROLES, ENERGY PROBLEMS AND HEALTH RELATED ISSUES,       
                 HAVE ALSO BEEN INVESTIGATED INTERMITTENTLY.                    
0                                                                               
                 EURO-BAROMETERS AVAILABLE FROM ICPSR:                          
0                                                                               
                 EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES STUDY, 1970 (ICPSR 7260)                  
                 EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES STUDY, 1971 (ICPSR 7275)                  
                 EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES STUDY, 1973 (ICPSR 7330)                  
                 EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES STUDY, 1973-1989: CUMULATIVE FILE         
                 (ICPSR 9361)                                                   
                 EURO-BAROMETER 3: EUROPEAN MEN AND WOMEN, MAY 1975             
                 (ICPSR 7416)                                                   
                 EURO-BAROMETER 4: CONSUMER ATTITUDES IN EUROPE,                
                 OCTOBER/NOVEMBER 1975 (ICPSR 7417)                             
                 EURO-BAROMETER 5: REVENUES, SATISFACTION, AND POVERTY, MAY     
                 1976 (ICPSR 7418)                                              
                 EURO-BAROMETER 6: TWENTY YEARS OF THE COMMON MARKET,           
                 OCTOBER/ NOVEMBER 1976 (ICPSR 7511)                            
                 EURO-BAROMETER 7: SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY IN THE EUROPEAN       
                 COMMUNITY, APRIL 1977 (ICPSR 7612)                             
                 EURO-BAROMETER 8: MEN, WOMEN AND WORK ROLES IN EUROPE,         
                 OCTOBER/NOVEMBER 1977 (ICPSR 7604)                             
                 EURO-BAROMETER 9: EMPLOYMENT AND UNEMPLOYMENT IN EUROPE,       
                 APRIL 1978 (ICPSR 7727)

                 OF EUROPE, OCTOBER/NOVEMBER 1978 (ICPSR 7728)

                 COMMUNITY, OCTOBER/NOVEMBER 1978 (ICPSR 7807)

0                                                                               
                 THIS SERIES OF SURVEYS WAS ORIGINALLY CONDUCTED UNDER THE      
                 DIRECTION OF JACQUES-RENE RABIER. SINCE 1987, DR. KARLHEINZ    
                 REIF AND DR. ANNA MELICH HAVE DIRECTED THE "SURVEYS,           
                 RESEARCH AND ANALYSIS" DIVISION OF THE COMMISSION OF THE       
1                                                                               
                                              III                               
0                                                                               
                 EUROPEAN COMMUNITY, UNDER THE DIRECTORATE GENERAL FOR          
                 INFORMATION, COMMUNICATION AND CULTURE. FROM THE START,        
                 RONALD INGLEHART OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN HAS HELPED      
                 MAKE THESE DATA AVAILABLE TO THE SOCIAL SCIENCE COMMUNITY      
                 THROUGH THE ICPSR. HE WISHES TO ACKNOWLEDGE THE SUPPORT OF     
                 THE NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION, GRANT NUMBERS SES 85-12100    
                 AND SES 88-09098 FOR THE CLEANING AND PROCESSING OF THE        
                 STUDY.                                                         
1                                                                               
                                              IV                                
1                                                                               
                                               V                                
0                                                                               
                                       STUDY DESCRIPTION                        
0                                                                               
                 THIS ROUND OF EURO-BAROMETER SURVEYS INVESTIGATED LIFE         
                 SATISFACTION, UNION MEMBERSHIP, SMOKING HABITS, KNOWLEDGE      
                 AND VIEWS REGARDING CANCER, VIEWS ON THE IMPORTANCE OF NATO    
                 AND CERTAIN NATIONAL PROBLEMS, ATTITUDES TOWARD DEMOCRACY      
                 AND INDIVIDUAL LIBERTIES, ATTITUDES TOWARD IMMIGRANTS AND      
                 OUT-GROUPS (I.E., PEOPLE OF ANOTHER NATIONALITY, RACE,         
                 RELIGION, CULTURE, OR SOCIAL CLASS), AND KNOWLEDGE OF AND      
                 ATTITUDES TOWARD EUROPEAN COMMUNITY INSTITUTIONS AND           
                 POLICIES, INCLUDING THE COMMON AGRICULTURAL POLICY AND THE     
                 CREATION OF A SINGLE EUROPEAN MARKET IN 1992. RESPONDENTS      
                 ALSO WERE ASKED TO NAME CURRENT TOPICS AND EVENTS MOST         
                 IMPORTANT FOR THEM AND TO STATE WHETHER OR NOT CERTAIN         
                 CAUSES SUCH AS THE PROTECTION OF WILDLIFE AND THE PROMOTION    
                 OF WORLD PEACE WERE WORTH TAKING RISKS AND MAKING SACRIFICES   
                 FOR. QUESTIONS ON POLITICAL PARTY PREFERENCES ASKED            
                 RESPONDENTS WHICH PARTY THEY FELT THE CLOSEST TO, HOW THEY     
                 VOTED IN THEIR COUNTRY'S LAST GENERAL ELECTION, HOW THEY       
                 WOULD VOTE IF A GENERAL ELECTION WERE HELD TOMORROW, AND HOW   
                 THEY PLANNED TO VOTE IN THE JUNE 1989 ELECTIONS FOR THE        
                 EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT. THE SURVEY ALSO GAUGED RESPONDENTS'       
                 PERCEPTIONS OF THE GENERAL ATTITUDE OF EACH COUNTRY'S          
                 POLITICAL PARTIES TOWARD THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY. THE INQUIRY   
                 INTO OUT-GROUPS ASKED RESPONDENTS TO IDENTIFY GROUPS THAT      
                 CAME TO MIND WHEN THEY THOUGHT OF PEOPLE OF ANOTHER            
                 NATIONALITY, RACE, RELIGION, CULTURE, OR SOCIAL CLASS.         
                 RESPONDENTS WERE ASKED IF THEY COUNTED ANY OUT-GROUP MEMBERS   
                 AMONG THEIR FRIENDS AND IF ANY OF THESE PERSONS WORKED AT      
                 THEIR PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT OR LIVED IN THEIR NEIGHBORHOODS.     
                 ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS ASKED RESPONDENTS IF THEY WERE            
                 DISTURBED BY THE PRESENCE OF THESE OUT-GROUPS AND IF THEY      
                 THOUGHT THAT THESE GROUPS EXPLOITED SOCIAL WELFARE BENEFITS,   
                 INCREASED UNEMPLOYMENT, CAUSED DELINQUENCY AND VIOLENCE,       
                 AFFECTED PROPERTY PRICES, OR REDUCED THE LEVEL OF EDUCATION    
                 IN SCHOOLS. IN WEST GERMANY, FRANCE, GREAT BRITAIN, AND THE    
                 NETHERLANDS, RESPONDENTS WERE QUERIED ABOUT THEIR ATTITUDES    
                 AND FEELINGS TOWARD SPECIFIC OUT-GROUPS: SOUTHERN EUROPEANS,   
                 NORTH AFRICANS, TURKS, BLACK AFRICANS, ASIANS, SOUTHEAST       
                 ASIANS, WEST INDIANS, JEWS, SURINAMERS AND NORTHERN            
                 EUROPEANS. THE SECTION ON CANCER QUERIED RESPONDENTS ABOUT     
                 THEIR KNOWLEDGE OF THE CAUSES OF CANCER AND MEDICAL            
                 RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ITS EARLY DETECTION AND PREVENTION, AND    
                 ASKED RESPONDENTS IF THEY FOLLOWED OR INTENDED TO FOLLOW       
                 THOSE RECOMMENDATIONS. ADDITIONAL INFORMATION GATHERED         
                 INCLUDES FAMILY INCOME, HOME OWNERSHIP, NUMBER OF PERSONS      
                 AND CHILDREN UNDER 15 RESIDING IN THE HOME, SIZE OF            
                 LOCALITY, REGION OF RESIDENCE, OCCUPATION OF THE HEAD OF       
1                                                                               
                                              VI                                
0                                                                               
                 HOUSEHOLD, AND THE RESPONDENT'S AGE, SEX, OCCUPATION,          
                 EDUCATION, RELIGION, RELIGIOSITY, SUBJECTIVE SOCIAL CLASS      
                 STANDING, AND LEFT-RIGHT POLITICAL SELF-PLACEMENT.             
-                                                                               
-                                                                               
                                     RELATED PUBLICATIONS                       
0                                                                               
                 RONALD INGLEHART, CULTURE SHIFT IN ADVANCED INDUSTRIAL         
                 SOCIETY. PRINCETON: PRINCETON UNIVERSITY PRESS, 1989.          
0                                                                               
                 KARLHEINZ REIF AND RONALD INGLEHART (EDS.), EURO-BAROMETER:    
                 THE DYNAMICS OF EUROPEAN OPINION. LONDON: MACMILLAN, 1991.     
1                                                                               
                                              VII                               
0                                                                               
                                    SAMPLING AND FIELDWORK                      
0                                                                               
                 INTERVIEWING AND SAMPLING WERE CONDUCTED BY VARIOUS RESEARCH   
                 FIRMS OPERATING IN THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY COUNTRIES.           
0                                                                               
                 FAITS ET OPINIONS DEVELOPED EQUIVALENT FRENCH AND ENGLISH      
                 QUESTIONNAIRES FOR THIS EURO-BAROMETER (SHOWN IN THE           
                 APPENDIX). THESE QUESTIONNAIRES WERE TRANSLATED TO LOCAL       
                 LANGUAGES BY THE FIRMS RESPONSIBLE FOR INTERVIEWING IN EACH    
                 COUNTRY. COPIES OF THESE QUESTIONNAIRES ARE AVAILABLE ON       
                 REQUEST FROM ICPSR.                                            
0                                                                               
                 THE EURO-BAROMETER SAMPLE WAS DESIGNED TO BE REPRESENTATIVE    
                 OF THE POPULATION AGED FIFTEEN AND OVER IN THE TWELVE          
                 COUNTRIES OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY.  A TWO-STAGE SAMPLING     
                 METHOD WAS USED IN EACH COUNTRY. IN THE FIRST STAGE, A         
                 RANDOM SELECTION OF SAMPLING POINTS WAS MADE FROM THE WHOLE    
                 TERRITORY OF EACH COUNTRY. VARIOUS TYPES OF AREA (URBAN,       
                 RURAL, ETC.) WERE REPRESENTED IN PROPORTION TO THEIR           
                 POPULATIONS. IN ALL, APPROXIMATELY 1,350 SAMPLING POINTS       
                 WERE SELECTED FROM ALL COUNTRIES. IN THE SECOND STAGE,         
                 INDIVIDUAL RESPONDENTS WERE SELECTED FROM THE SAMPLING         
                 POINTS OBTAINED IN THE FIRST STAGE.                            
0                                                                               
                 THREE METHODS OF SELECTION WERE USED IN THE SECOND STAGE:      
                                                                                
                 A. IN DENMARK, LUXEMBOURG AND NETHERLANDS, RESPONDENTS WERE    
                 SELECTED AT RANDOM FROM POPULATION REGISTERS OR ELECTORAL      
                 LISTS.                                                         
                                                                                
                 B.  IN BELGIUM, FRANCE, ITALY, THE UNITED KINGDOM AND          
                 IRELAND, RESPONDENTS WERE SELECTED BY QUOTA SAMPLING. CENSUS   
                 DATA WAS USED TO ESTABLISH QUOTAS BY AGE, SEX AND              
                 OCCUPATION.                                                    
                                                                                
                 C. IN GERMANY, GREECE, SPAIN AND PORTUGAL, RESPONDENTS WERE    
                 SELECTED BY "RANDOM ROUTE," A COMBINATION OF METHODS A AND     
                 B.                                                             
0                                                                               
                 THE FIRMS RESPONSIBLE FOR CARRYING OUT EACH NATIONAL SURVEY    
                 ARE SHOWN BELOW, TOGETHER WITH INTERVIEWING DATES FOR EACH     
                 COUNTRY. DATA USERS SHOULD CONTACT THESE ORGANIZATIONS FOR     
                 MORE DETAILED INFORMATION REGARDING SAMPLING METHODS.          
1                                                                               
                                             VIII                               
0

1                                                                               
                                              IX                                
0                                                                               
                                     WEIGHTING INFORMATION                      
0                                                                               
                 THIS EURO-BAROMETER CONTAINS BOTH WEIGHTED AND                 
                 SELF-WEIGHTING (UNWEIGHTED) NATIONAL SAMPLES:                  
0                                                                               
                     WEIGHTED: DENMARK           SELF-WEIGHTING: BELGIUM        
                               SPAIN                             ITALY          
                               GERMANY                           LUXEMBOURG     
                               FRANCE                            IRELAND        
                               NETHERLANDS                       PORTUGAL       
                               UNITED KINGDOM                    GREECE         
0                                                                               
                 THE WEIGHTED SAMPLES REQUIRE THE APPLICATION OF WEIGHTS TO     
                 MAKE THEM REPRESENTATIVE OF THE COUNTRIES FROM WHICH THEY      
                 WERE DRAWN. THE SELF-WEIGHTING SAMPLES DO NOT REQUIRE          
                 ADJUSTMENT BY WEIGHTS FOR INDIVIDUAL COUNTRY ANALYSES.         
0                                                                               
                 THREE WEIGHT VARIABLES ARE PROVIDED IN THIS DATASET: NATION    
                 WEIGHT I (VARIABLE 6), NATION WEIGHT II (VARIABLE 8) AND       
                 EUROPEAN WEIGHT (VARIABLE 9).                                  
0                                                                               
                 NATION WEIGHT I CONTAINS WEIGHTS THAT ADJUST THE WEIGHTED      
                 SAMPLES TO MAKE THEM REPRESENTATIVE OF THE COUNTRIES FROM      
                 WHICH THEY WERE DRAWN. THESE WEIGHTS ARE SCALED SO THAT THE    
                 SUM OF THE WEIGHTS FOR EACH COUNTRY EQUALS THE NUMBER OF       
                 RESPONDENTS WHO WERE INTERVIEWED THERE. NATION WEIGHT I        
                 EQUALS ONE FOR ALL RESPONDENTS WHO WERE INTERVIEWED IN         
                 COUNTRIES WITH SELF-WEIGHTING SAMPLES. THIS WEIGHT VARIABLE    
                 SHOULD BE USED WHENEVER COUNTRIES WITH WEIGHTED SAMPLES ARE    
                 TO BE ANALYZED SEPARATELY.                                     
0                                                                               
                 NATION WEIGHT II ALLOWS FOR SEPARATE ANALYSES OF GREAT         
                 BRITAIN AND NORTHERN IRELAND. THE WEIGHTS ASSIGNED TO          
                 RESPONDENTS IN GREAT BRITAIN PRODUCE A REPRESENTATIVE SAMPLE   
                 FOR GREAT BRITAIN ALONE. NO WEIGHTS NEED BE APPLIED TO         
                 SEPARATELY ANALYZE NORTHERN IRELAND, SINCE THE SAMPLE          
                 SELECTED THERE WAS SELF-WEIGHTING. THUS, THIS WEIGHT           
                 VARIABLE EQUALS ONE FOR ALL RESPONDENTS IN NORTHERN IRELAND.   
                 FOR ALL OTHER COUNTRIES OUTSIDE THE UNITED KINGDOM, NATION     
                 WEIGHT II IS IDENTICAL TO NATION WEIGHT I, EXCEPT FOR SOME     
                 VERY SLIGHT DIFFERENCES DUE TO ROUNDING.                       
1                                                                               
                                               X                                
0                                                                               
                 EUROPEAN WEIGHT CONTAINS WEIGHTS THAT ADJUST EACH NATIONAL     
                 SAMPLE IN PROPORTION TO ITS NATION'S SHARE IN THE TOTAL        
                 POPULATION OF ALL THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY COUNTRIES. THIS       
                 WEIGHT VARIABLE ALSO INCORPORATES THE WITHIN-COUNTRY           
                 WEIGHTING INFORMATION CONTAINED IN NATION WEIGHT I. EUROPEAN   
                 WEIGHT MAY BE USED TO ANALYZE THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY NATIONS   
                 AS A WHOLE.

                 COUNTRY:

                 PORTUGAL            1,000         1,000.00           339.63    
                                                                                
                                                                                
                 TOTAL              11,791        11,791.00        11,793.66    
1                                                                               
                                              XI                                
0                                                                               
                                     CODEBOOK INFORMATION                       
0                                                                               
                 THE EXAMPLE BELOW IS A REPRODUCTION OF INFORMATION APPEARING   
                 IN THE MACHINE-READABLE CODEBOOK FOR A TYPICAL VARIABLE. THE   
                 NUMBERS IN BRACKETS DO NOT APPEAR BUT ARE REFERENCES TO THE    
                 DESCRIPTIONS WHICH FOLLOW THIS EXAMPLE.                        
                                                                                
                 ............................................................   
                                                                                
                 [1] VAR 15    [2] GENERAL ECONOMIC SITUAT           [3] MD=0   
                     REF 15     [4] LOC   37  WIDTH  1    [5] DK  1 COL 39      
0                                                                               
                 [6] Q.116.  HOW DO YOU THINK THE GENERAL ECONOMIC SITUATION    
                     IN THIS COUNTRY HAS CHANGED OVER THE LAST 12 MONTHS?       
                     -------------------------------------------------------    
                                                                                
                      [7]  [8]                                                  
                                                                                
                       1.  GOT A LOT BETTER                                     
                       2.  GOT A LITTLE BETTER                                  
                       3.  GOT A LITTLE WORSE                                   
                       4.  GOT A LOT WORSE                                      
                       5.  STAYED THE SAME                                      
                                                                                
                       0.  DK/NA                                                
                                                                                
                 ............................................................   
0                                                                               
                 [1]  INDICATES THE VARIABLE AND REFERENCE NUMBERS.             
                      A VARIABLE NUMBER AND A REFERENCE NUMBER ARE              
                      ASSIGNED TO EACH VARIABLE IN THE DATA COLLECTION.         
                      IN THE PRESENT CODEBOOK WHICH DOCUMENTS THE               
                      ARCHIVED DATA COLLECTION THESE NUMBERS ARE                
                      IDENTICAL.  SHOULD THE DATA BE SUBSETTED OR               
                      REARRANGED BY AN OSIRIS PROGRAM (E.G., MMP TO             
                      INTERSPERSE DATA FROM ANOTHER SOURCE, OR TCOT TO          
                      PRODUCE AN ANALYSIS DECK), THE VARIABLE NUMBERS           
                      WOULD CHANGE TO REFLECT THE ORDER OF THE NEW DATA         
                      COLLECTION, WHILE THE REFERENCE NUMBER WOULD REMAIN       
                      UNCHANGED TO REFLECT THE VARIABLE NUMBER IN THE           
                      CODEBOOK DESCRIBING THE ARCHIVED DATA COLLECTION.         
1                                                                               
                                              XII                               
                                                                                
                 [2]  INDICATES THE ABBREVIATED VARIABLE NAME (MAXIMUM          
                      OF 24 CHARACTERS) USED TO IDENTIFY THE VARIABLE           
                      FOR THE USER.  AN EXPANDED VERSION OF THE VARIABLE        
                      NAME CAN BE FOUND IN THE VARIABLE DESCRIPTION LIST.       
                                                                                
                 [3]  INDICATES THE CODE VALUES OF MISSING DATA.  IN            
                      THIS EXAMPLE, 0 IS MISSING DATA.  AN ALTERNATIVE          
                      STATEMENT FOUND IN OTHER VARIABLES IS MD GE 8,            
                      INDICATING ANY CODE GREATER THAN OR EQUAL TO              
                      8 IS MISSING DATA, OR "NO MISSING DATA CODES."            
                      SOME ANALYSIS SOFTWARE PACKAGES (INCLUDING THE OSIRIS     
                      SOFTWARE PACKAGE) REQUIRE THAT CERTAIN TYPES OF DATA      
                      WHICH THE USER DESIRES TO BE EXCLUDED FROM ANALYSIS       
                      BE DESIGNATED AS "MISSING DATA," E.G., INAPPROPRIATE,     
                      UNASCERTAINED, UNASCERTAINABLE, OR AMBIGUOUS DATA         
                      CATEGORIES.  ALTHOUGH THESE CODES ARE DEFINED AS          
                      MISSING DATA CATEGORIES, THIS DOES NOT MEAN THAT THE      
                      USER SHOULD NOT OR CANNOT USE THEM IN A SUBSTANTIVE       
                      ROLE IF SO DESIRED.                                       
                                                                                
                 [4]  INDICATES THE STARTING LOCATION AND WIDTH OF THIS         
                      VARIABLE WHEN THE DATA ARE STORED ON A MAGNETIC TAPE      
                      IN LRECL FORMAT.  IF THE VARIABLE IS OF A                 
                      MULTIPLE-RESPONSE TYPE, THE WIDTH REFERENCED IS THAT      
                      OF A SINGLE RESPONSE.  IN THIS EXAMPLE THE VARIABLE       
                      NAMED "GENERAL ECONOMIC SITUAT" IS 1 COLUMN WIDE AND IS   
                      LOCATED IN THE 36TH COLUMN OF THE RECORD.                 
                                                                                
                 [5]  INDICATES THE LOCATION BY DECK AND COLUMN(S) OF THIS      
                      VARIABLE WHEN THE DATA ARE STORED ON CARDS OR IN          
                      CARD-IMAGE FORMAT (80-COLUMN FORMAT).                     
                                                                                
                 [6]  THIS IS THE FULL TEXT (QUESTION) SUPPLIED BY THE          
                      INVESTIGATOR TO DESCRIBE THE VARIABLE.  THE QUESTION      
                      TEXT AND THE NUMBERS AND LETTERS THAT MAY APPEAR AT       
                      THE BEGINNING REFLECT THE ORIGINAL WORDING OF THE         
                      QUESTIONNAIRE ITEM.                                       
                                                                                
                 [7]  INDICATES THE CODE VALUES OCCURRING IN THE DATA FOR       
                      THIS VARIABLE.                                            
                                                                                
                 [8]  INDICATES THE TEXTUAL DEFINITIONS OF THE CODES.           
                      ABBREVIATIONS COMMONLY USED IN THE CODE DEFINITIONS       
                      ARE "DK" (DO NOT KNOW), "NA" (NOT ASCERTAINED), AND       
                      "INAP." (INAPPROPRIATE).                                  
1                                                                               
                                             XIII                               
0                                                                               
                                DATA PREPARATION AND FORMATTING                 
0                                                                               
                 THE DATA RECEIVED BY ICPSR FROM FAITS ET OPINIONS WERE         
                 CHECKED FOR MISSING AND DUPLICATE RECORDS, FOR ILLEGAL         
                 (WILD) CODES AND FOR CONSISTENCY OF RESPONSE PATTERNS.         
                 ERRORS DISCOVERED BY THESE PROCEDURES WERE CORRECTED OR        
                 NOTED IN THIS CODEBOOK. INDICES AND OTHER DERIVED SUMMARY      
                 VARIABLES WERE ALSO CHECKED AND CORRECTED AS NECESSARY.        
                 COMPLETE MACHINE-READABLE DOCUMENTATION WAS ALSO CREATED FOR   
                 THIS DATASET BY ICPSR.                                         
0                                                                               
                 TO FACILITATE ANALYSES OF THE DATA, ICPSR CREATED NEW          
                 VARIABLES WHICH CONSOLIDATE INFORMATION DISPERSED OVER TWO     
                 OR MORE VARIABLES IN THE ORIGINAL FAITS ET OPINIONS DATASET.   
                 IN ALL, TEN VARIABLES CONTAINING CONDENSED INFORMATION WERE    
                 CREATED FOR THIS EURO-BAROMETER: NATION II, EURO VOTE JUNE     
                 89, PARTY PREFERENCE, VOTE INTENTION, PARTY LAST VOTE,         
                 INCOME, UNION MEMBERSHIP, OBJ TOWN SIZE, PROVINCE AND          
                 REGION. USERS SHOULD BE AWARE THAT ICPSR'S PROCESS OF          
                 CONDENSING INFORMATION SOMETIMES PRODUCES CODING SCHEMES       
                 THAT DIFFER FROM THOSE IN EARLIER EURO-BAROMETERS.             
0                                                                               
                 ICPSR ALSO ADDED "INAPPROPRIATE" CODES TO INDICATE             
                 INTENTIONALLY SKIPPED QUESTIONS WHEN IT COULD BE DETERMINED    
                 THAT THE APPROPRIATE SKIP INSTRUCTION IN THE FAITS ET          
                 OPINIONS QUESTIONNAIRE WAS ADHERED TO FOR EVERY RESPONDENT.    
0                                                                               
                 USERS SHOULD NOTE THAT FAITS ET OPINIONS OFTEN REPRESENTS      
                 ANSWERS TO A QUESTION BY A SERIES OF BINARY VARIABLES (I.E.    
                 VARIABLES WHICH TAKE ON VALUES OF ONE AND ZERO ONLY) WITHOUT   
                 EXPLICITLY REPRESENTING "DON'T KNOW" OR "NO ANSWER"            
                 RESPONSES. OCCASIONALLY, OTHER RESIDUAL RESPONSES, SUCH AS     
                 "NONE OF THE ABOVE," ALSO ARE NOT EXPLICITLY REPRESENTED IN    
                 THE DATA. EXCEPT FOR RECODING WITH "INAPPROPRIATE" CODES, AS   
                 DESCRIBED ABOVE, ICPSR HAS NOT RECODED THESE VARIABLES TO      
                 INDICATE RESIDUAL RESPONSES. CONSEQUENTLY, USERS WILL HAVE     
                 TO DEVISE THEIR OWN METHODS TO FILTER THEM OUT.                
0                                                                               
                 USERS SHOULD ALSO NOTE THAT ON OCCASION THE NUMBER OF          
                 RESPONSES TO A PARTICULAR QUESTION MAY EXCEED THE MAXIMUM      
                 INDICATED IN THE INTERVIEWER INSTRUCTIONS.                     
1                                                                               
                                              XIV                               
0                                                                               
                 QUESTION TEXT AND CONTINGENCY TEXT APPEARING IN THIS           
                 CODEBOOK AND ICPSR'S MACHINE-READABLE DOCUMENTATION IS TAKEN   
                 FROM FAITS ET OPINIONS' ENGLISH LANGUAGE VERSION OF THE        
                 QUESTIONNAIRE. CODING SCHEMES AND OTHER DOCUMENTATION ARE      
                 BASED ON FAITS ET OPINIONS' ENGLISH LANGUAGE VERSION OF THE    
                 QUESTIONNAIRE, FAITS ET OPINIONS' CODEBOOK (IN FRENCH) AND     
                 AN OSIRIS DICTIONARY PROVIDED BY RONALD INGLEHART. WHENEVER    
                 A DISCREPANCY OCCURS BETWEEN FAITS ET OPINIONS' CODEBOOK AND   
                 ITS ENGLISH LANGUAGE QUESTIONNAIRE AS TO THE CODING SCHEME     
                 OF A VARIABLE, THE FORMER IS FOLLOWED BY ICPSR IN ITS          
                 DOCUMENTATION. ANGLE BRACKETS (< >) APPEARING IN THE           
                 CODEBOOK DELINEATE EXPLANATORY TEXT ADDED BY ICPSR.            
0                                                                               
                 THE CODEBOOK CONTAINS WEIGHTED FREQUENCY COUNTS, BY COUNTRY,   
                 FOR ALL OF THE VARIABLES IN THIS EURO-BAROMETER EXCEPT         
                 VARIABLES 1-9, 680, 682, 683, 690 AND 733. ALL FREQUENCY       
                 COUNTS - INCLUDING ROW AND COLUMN TOTALS - ARE WEIGHTED BY     
                 NATION WEIGHT I (VARIABLE 6) OR NATION WEIGHT II (VARIABLE     
                 8). NATION WEIGHT I WAS USED FOR TABLES HAVING A SINGLE ROW    
                 FOR THE UNITED KINGDOM; NATION WEIGHT II WAS USED FOR TABLES   
                 WITH SEPARATE ROWS FOR GREAT BRITAIN AND NORTHERN IRELAND.     
                 ALL FREQUENCY COUNTS ARE ROUNDED TO THE NEAREST WHOLE          
                 NUMBER.                                                        
0                                                                               
                 THIS EURO-BAROMETER IS AVAILABLE FROM ICPSR IN TWO FORMATS:    
                 CARD IMAGE AND OSIRIS. THE CARD-IMAGE FILE CONTAINS 13 DECKS   
                 PER CASE IN A FORMAT BASED ON 80-CHARACTER RECORDS. THE        
                 OSIRIS DATA FILE IS CONSTRUCTED WITH A SINGLE LOGICAL          
                 RECORD, WITH A LENGTH OF 798, PER RESPONDENT. THIS CODEBOOK    
                 GIVES VARIABLE LOCATIONS FOR BOTH FORMATS.                     
0                                                                               
                 AN OSIRIS DICTIONARY AND DICTIONARY-CODEBOOK ARE ALSO          
                 AVAILABLE FOR THE OSIRIS DATA FILE. THESE MAY BE USED IN       
                 CONJUNCTION WITH THE OSIRIS SOFTWARE PACKAGE, OR TO            
                 INTERFACE WITH OTHER STATISTICAL SOFTWARE SUCH AS SPSS OR      
                 SAS.                                                           
0                                                                               
                 SPSS CONTROL CARDS HAVE ALSO BEEN PREPARED BY ICPSR FOR THE    
                 OSIRIS DATA FILE AND THE CARD-IMAGE FILE. THESE CONTROL        
                 CARDS CONTAIN FORMATTING INFORMATION AS WELL AS VARIABLE AND   
                 VALUE LABELS FOR ALL THE VARIABLES IN THE COLLECTION.          
1                                                                               
                                              XV                                
0                                                                               
                 NOTE: ICPSR DID NOT RECEIVE DOCUMENTATION FOR CATEGORY 5 IN    
                 THE FRENCH CLASSIFICATION SCHEME FOR Q.245/249. ICPSR IS       
                 CONTINUING ITS EFFORTS TO OBTAIN THIS MISSING INFORMATION.     
0                                                                               
                 RECODING OF R'S AGE IN YEARS (VARIABLE 690): THE ORIGINAL      
                 GREAT BRITAIN DATA FOR VARIABLE 690 INCORRECTLY RECORDED THE   
                 LAST TWO DIGITS OF YEAR OF BIRTH, INSTEAD OF AGE AT TIME OF    
                 INTERVIEW. ICPSR HANDLED THIS PROBLEM BY RECODING THE          
                 BRITISH DATA: YEAR OF BIRTH WAS CONVERTED TO AGE BY ASSUMING   
                 THAT THE BIRTHDAYS OF ALL BRITISH RESPONDENTS PRECEDED THEIR   
                 EURO-BAROMETER INTERVIEWS. ICPSR WAS UNABLE TO RECONSTRUCT     
                 THE AGES OF PERSONS BORN BEFORE 1915. CONSEQUENTLY, FOR        
                 VARIABLE 690, CODE 73 IS DEFINED AS "AGES 73 AND OVER" FOR     
                 RESPONDENTS IN GREAT BRITAIN.                                  
1                                                                               
                                              XVI                               
1                                                                               
                                             XVII                               
0                                                                               
                              CHANGES IN THE SECOND ICPSR EDITION               
0                                                                               
                 THE SECOND EDITION OF EURO-BAROMETER 30: IMMIGRANTS AND        
                 OUT-GROUPS IN WESTERN EUROPE, OCTOBER-NOVEMBER 1988 NOW        
                 INCLUDES DATA FOR THE QUESTIONS THAT WERE PREVIOUSLY           
                 SUPPRESSED WITH MASKING CODES.  THESE QUESTIONS AND THE        
                 VARIABLES THEY COMPRISE ARE LISTED BELOW:                      
                                                                                
                 Q.420/421: ITEMS Q.420/421(1) THROUGH Q.420/421(12)            
                 (VARIABLES 530-541)                                            
                                                                                
                 Q.439/440 (VARIABLE 559)                                       
                                                                                
                 Q.452/459: ITEMS Q.452 THROUGH Q.459 (VARIABLES 580-587)       
0                                                                               
                 REFERENCES TO THE MASKING CODES FORMERLY FOUND IN THE          
                 DESCRIPTIONS OF THE PREVIOUSLY SUPPRESSED VARIABLES HAVE       
                 BEEN DROPPED FROM THE SECOND EDITION OF THE OSIRIS             
                 CODEBOOK-DICTIONARY AND THE FORMATTED CODEBOOK.  OTHER         
                 CHANGES TO THE OSIRIS CODEBOOK-DICTIONARY AND THE FORMATTED    
                 CODEBOOK INCLUDE UPDATES TO THE FRONT MATTER AND               
                 INTRODUCTION.  IN ADDITION, THE WEIGHTED FREQUENCY COUNTS      
                 THAT WERE FORMERLY FOUND IN THE APPENDIX ARE NOW MERGED INTO   
                 THE THE MAIN BODY OF THE CODEBOOKS.                            
0                                                                               
                 THE MISSING DATA DECLARATIONS FOUND IN THE OSIRIS              
                 CODEBOOK-DICTIONARY AND THE SPSS CONTROL CARDS FOR             
                 Q.420/421: ITEMS Q.420/421(1) THROUGH Q.420/421(12)            
                 (VARIABLES 530-541), Q.452 AND Q.453 (VARIABLES 580-581),      
                 AND Q.456 THROUGH Q.459 (VARIABLES 584-587) HAVE BEEN          
                 ADJUSTED TO REFLECT THE VALUES FOUND IN THE SECOND EDITION     
                 DATA AFTER THE MASKING CODES WERE DROPPED.                     
0                                                                               
                 THE ONLY ADDITIONAL CHANGE TO THE DATA IS AN UPDATE OF THE     
                 ICPSR EDITION NUMBER (VARIABLE 2) TO '2'.

                                             XXII                               
                                                                                
                        Q.141/145. COULD YOU TELL ME FOR EACH OF THE            
                        RECOMMENDATIONS..., IF IT IS IMPORTANT, FAIRLY          
                        IMPORTANT OR NOT IMPORTANT IN REDUCING THE RISKS OF     
                        CANCER?                                                 
                                                                                
                    78  Q.141. DO NOT SMOKE                                     
                    79  Q.142. MODERATE YOUR CONSUMPTION OF ALCOHOLIC DRINKS    
                    80  Q.143. AVOID EXCESSIVE EXPOSURE TO THE SUN              
                    81  Q.144. EAT FRESH FRUITS AND VEGETABLES FREQUENTLY       
                    82  Q.145. AVOID BEING OVERWEIGHT                           
                                                                                
                        Q.146/150. ...FOR EACH OF THESE RECOMMENDATIONS,        
                        WOULD YOU SAY THAT YOU ARE FOLLOWING IT ALREADY, YOU    
                        HAVE THE INTENTION TO TRY AND FOLLOW IT, OR YOU DON'T   
                        INTEND TO TRY?                                          
                                                                                
                    83  Q.146. DO NOT SMOKE                                     
                    84  Q.147. MODERATE YOUR CONSUMPTION OF ALCOHOLIC DRINKS    
                    85  Q.148. AVOID EXCESSIVE EXPOSURE TO THE SUN              
                    86  Q.149. EAT FRESH FRUITS AND VEGETABLES FREQUENTLY       
                    87  Q.150. AVOID BECOMING OVERWEIGHT                        
                                                                                
                        Q.151/152. ...PLEASE TELL ME IF IT IS IMPORTANT,        
                        FAIRLY IMPORTANT, OR NOT IMPORTANT AT ALL IN            
                        LESSENING THE RISKS OF CANCER?                          
                                                                                
                    88  Q.151  HAVE A CERVICAL SMEAR REGULARLY                  
                    89  Q.152. CHECK YOUR BREASTS REGULARLY                     
                                                                                
                        Q.153/154. ...DO YOU DO IT REGULARLY, FROM TIME TO      
                        TIME OR NOT AT ALL?                                     
                                                                                
                    90  Q.153. HAVE A CERVICAL SMEAR REGULARLY                  
                    91  Q.154. CHECK YOUR BREASTS REGULARLY                     
                                                                                
                        SMOKING HABITS; HEALTH, EDUCATION PROFESSION            
                                                                                
                        Q.155. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING THINGS APPLIES TO YOU?    
                                                                                
                    92  Q.155(1). YOU SMOKE CIGARETTES                          
                    93  Q.155(2). YOU SMOKE CIGARS OR A PIPE

                    95  Q.155(4). YOU HAVE NEVER SMOKED

                        OR NOT...?

                        ONE OF THE HEALTH PROFESSIONS...?                       
1                                                                               
                                             XXIII                              
                                                                                
                    98  Q.158. AND DO ANY OF YOUR IMMEDIATE FAMILY...BELONG     
                        TO THESE HEALTH PROFESSIONS?

                   361  Q.245/249(R). <OPINION OF THE "SINGLE EUROPEAN          
                        MARKET" OR "1992," ON BALANCE>                          
                                                                                
                        Q.250/252. CAN YOU TELL ME, FOR EACH ASPECT OF          
                        THIS SINGLE COMMON EUROPEAN MARKET WHICH I AM GOING     
                        TO MENTION, WHETHER YOU PERSONALLY THINK IT WILL BE     
                        AN ADVANTAGE OR A DISADVANTAGE?                         
                                                                                
                   362  Q.250/252(1). ELIMINATION OF CUSTOM CONTROLS WHEN       
                        CROSSING FRONTIERS BETWEEN COUNTRIES INSIDE THE         
                        EUROPEAN COMMUNITY                                      
                   363  Q.250/252(2). THE OPPORTUNITY FOR ANY CITIZEN OF A      
                        COUNTRY WITHIN THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY TO GO AND LIVE    
                        WITHOUT LIMITATION IN ANY OTHER COUNTRY OF THE          
                        COMMUNITY, FOR INSTANCE TO RETIRE THERE OR TO STUDY     
                        THERE                                                   
                   364  Q.250/252(3). THE OPPORTUNITY FOR ANY CITIZEN OF A      
                        COUNTRY WITHIN THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY TO GO AND WORK    
                        IN ANY OTHER COUNTRY OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY          
                   365  Q.250/252(4). THE POSSIBILITY TO BUY IN ONE'S OWN       
                        COUNTRY ANY PRODUCT LAWFULLY SOLD IN OTHER COUNTRIES    
                        OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY                               
                   366  Q.250/252(5). BRINGING CLOSER TOGETHER THE RATES OF     
                        VAT (VALUE ADDED TAX) APPLIED IN THE VARIOUS            
                        COUNTRIES OF THE COMMUNITY SO THAT PRODUCTS ARE SOLD    
                        UNDER SIMILAR COST CONDITIONS                           
                   367  Q.250/252(6). THE ABILITY TO MAKE PAYMENTS WITHOUT      
                        COMPLICATION WITHIN THE WHOLE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY        
                   368  Q.250/252(7). THE ABILITY TO TAKE ANY AMOUNT OF MONEY   
                        WITH YOU WHEN YOU TRAVEL TO OTHER COUNTRIES OF THE      
                        EUROPEAN COMMUNITY                                      
                   369  Q.250/252(8). THE POSSIBILITY TO BUY LAND OR            
                        PROPERTY THROUGHOUT THE COMMUNITY                       
                   370  Q.250/252(9). THE POSSIBILITY TO OPEN A BANK ACCOUNT    
                        IN ANY COUNTRY OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY                
                   371  Q.250/252(10). THE POSSIBILITY FOR A CONTRACTOR FROM    
                        ANOTHER COMMUNITY COUNTRY TO BE IN CHARGE OF PUBLIC     
                        WORKS....

                        YOU SAY THAT (YOUR COUNTRY) HAS ON BALANCE BENEFITED    
                        OR NOT FROM BEING A MEMBER OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY    
                        (COMMON MARKET)?                                        
1

                 SEPARATE)                                                      
                 ----------------------------------------------------           
                                                                                
                 <THIS WEIGHT VARIABLE ALLOWS FOR SEPARATE ANALYSES OF          
                 RESPONDENTS IN GREAT BRITAIN AND NORTHERN IRELAND.             
                 RESPONDENTS WHO WERE INTERVIEWED IN GREAT BRITAIN ARE          
                 ASSIGNED WEIGHTING FACTORS REPRESENTING GREAT BRITAIN ALONE    
                 INSTEAD OF THE UNITED KINGDOM AS A WHOLE. THE NORTHERN         
                 IRELAND SAMPLE IS SELF-WEIGHTING. THUS, NATION WEIGHT II       
                 EQUALS ONE FOR ALL NORTHERN IRELAND RESPONDENTS. FOR           
                 COUNTRIES OTHER THAN THE UNITED KINGDOM, NATION WEIGHT II IS   
                 THE SAME AS NATION WEIGHT I EXCEPT FOR SOME SLIGHT             
                 DIFFERENCES DUE TO ROUNDING. SEE INTRODUCTION, WEIGHTING       
                 INFORMATION.>

0                                                                               
                 Q.164.  WHICH OF THESE TWO STATEMENTS COMES CLOSEST TO YOUR    
                 OWN OPINION?  (SHOW LIST)                                      
                 -----------------------------------------------------------    
                                                                                
                     1.  I FIND THAT BOTH FREEDOM AND EQUALITY ARE IMPORTANT.   
                         BUT IF I WERE TO MAKE UP MY MIND FOR ONE OR THE        
                         OTHER, I WOULD CONSIDER PERSONAL FREEDOM MORE          
                         IMPORTANT, THAT IS EVERYONE CAN LIVE IN FREEDOM AND    
                         DEVELOP WITHOUT HINDRANCE                              
                     2.  CERTAINLY BOTH FREEDOM AND EQUALITY ARE IMPORTANT.     
                         BUT IF I WERE TO MAKE UP MY MIND FOR ONE OF THE TWO,   
                         I WOULD CONSIDER EQUALITY MORE IMPORTANT, THAT IS      
                         THAT NOBODY IS UNDERPRIVILEGED AND THAT SOCIAL CLASS   
                         DIFFERENCES ARE NOT SO STRONG                          
                     3.  NEITHER                                                
                                                                                
                     0.  DK/NA                                                  
0                                                                               
                         0.    1.    2.    3.   TOT                             
                 FRA     18   445   484    54  1001                             
                 BEL     37   504   394    89  1024

                 Q.165.  HERE ARE THREE OPINIONS ABOUT POLITICAL SYSTEMS        
                 (SHOW CARD). WHICH ONE COMES CLOSEST TO YOUR OWN WAY OF        
                 THINKING?                                                      
                 -------------------------------------------------------        
                                                                                
                     1.  DEMOCRACY IS THE BEST POLITICAL SYSTEM IN ALL          
                         CIRCUMSTANCES                                          
                     2.  IN CERTAIN CIRCUMSTANCES A DICTATORSHIP COULD BE A     
                         GOOD THING                                             
                     3.  WHETHER WE LIVE IN A DEMOCRACY OR UNDER A              
                         DICTATORSHIP MAKES NO DIFFERENCE TO PEOPLE LIKE ME     
                                                                                
                     0.  DK/NA                                                  
0                                                                               
                         0.    1.    2.    3.   TOT                             
                 FRA     15   769    55   162  1001                             
                 BEL     16   770   117   121  1024                             
                 NL      12   844    64    86  1006                             
                 GER      6   860   118    68  1051                             
                 ITA      3   781   141   133  1058                             
                 LUX      3   245    14    38   300

                 Q.173/174.  WHEN YOU HEAR ABOUT PEOPLE OF ANOTHER

                 Q.173/174(1).  <RESPONSE CLASSIFIED AS CATEGORY 1>: SOUTH      
                 EUROPEANS (PEOPLE FROM SPAIN, ITALY, GREECE, PORTUGAL)

                 Q.245/249.  WHAT COMES TO YOUR MIND WHEN YOU HEAR "SINGLE      
                 EUROPEAN MARKET" OR "1992"?  PLEASE TELL ALL THE THINGS THAT

                 Q.250/252.  THE COMING INTO BEING OF THE SINGLE COMMON         
                 EUROPEAN MARKET IN 1992 WILL MEAN THE FREE CIRCULATION OF      
                 PERSONS, GOODS, AND PROPERTY WITHIN THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY     
                 COUNTRIES.  SOME PEOPLE THINK THIS WILL BE MOSTLY AN           
                 ADVANTAGE, OTHERS THINK IT WILL BE A DISADVANTAGE.  CAN YOU    
                 TELL ME, FOR EACH ASPECT OF THIS SINGLE COMMON EUROPEAN        
                 MARKET WHICH I AM GOING TO MENTION, WHETHER YOU PERSONALLY     
                 THINK IT WILL BE AN ADVANTAGE OR A DISADVANTAGE?  (ONE         
                 ANSWER PER LINE)                                               
                                                                                
                 Q.250/252(1).  ELIMINATION OF CUSTOM CONTROLS WHEN CROSSING    
                 FRONTIERS BETWEEN COUNTRIES INSIDE THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY

                 GROUPS ON THIS LIST (SHOW LIST).  I WOULD LIKE YOU TO RATE     
                 EACH OF THEM ON A SCALE THAT RUNS FROM 0 TO 100. RATINGS       
                 BETWEEN 51 AND 100 MEAN THAT YOU FEEL FAVORABLE TOWARD THAT    
                 GROUP.  RATINGS BETWEEN 0 AND 49 MEAN THAT YOU DON'T FEEL      
                 TOO FAVORABLE TOWARD THAT GROUP.  A RATING OF 50 MEANS THAT    
                 YOU DON'T FEEL PARTICULARLY FAVORABLE OR UNFAVORABLE TOWARD

                 Q.331.  SUPPOSE THAT YOU HAVE CHILDREN WITH A PERSON OF VERY   
                 DIFFERENT COLOR AND PHYSICAL CHARACTERISTICS THAN YOUR OWN.    
                 DO YOU THINK THAT YOU WOULD BE VERY BOTHERED, BOTHERED,        
                 BOTHERED A LITTLE, OR NOT BOTHERED AT ALL, IF THE CHILDREN     
                 DO NOT PHYSICALLY RESEMBLE THE PEOPLE ON YOUR SIDE OF THE      
                 FAMILY?                                                        
                 ------------------------------------------------------------   
                                                                                
                     1.  VERY BOTHERED                                          
                     2.  BOTHERED                                               
                     3.  BOTHERED A LITTLE                                      
                     4.  NOT BOTHERED AT ALL

                 Q.477.  ON THIS CARD ARE THREE BASIC KINDS OF ATTITUDES        
                 VIS-A-VIS THE SOCIETY WE LIVE IN.  PLEASE CHOOSE THE ONE       
                 WHICH BEST DESCRIBES YOUR OWN OPINION.  (SHOW CARD, ONE        
                 ANSWER ONLY).                                                  
                 --------------------------------------------------------       
                                                                                
                     1.  THE ENTIRE WAY OUR SOCIETY IS ORGANIZED MUST BE        
                         RADICALLY CHANGED BY REVOLUTIONARY ACTION              
                     2.  OUR SOCIETY MUST BE GRADUALLY IMPROVED BY REFORM

                         AGAINST ALL SUBVERSIVE FORCES

0                                                                               
                         0.    1.    2.    3.   TOT                             
                 FRA     32    43   691   235  1001

                 CHAPTER 11. THIS VARIABLE IS LABELED THE OPINION LEADERSHIP    
                 INDEX IN THE CODEBOOKS FOR EURO-BAROMETERS 3, 4, 5 AND 6.>

0                                                                               
                 FRONTIER ZONE                                                  
                 -------------                                                  
                                                                                
                 <THIS VARIABLE SIGNALS ADJACENCY TO ANOTHER E.C. COUNTRY.      
                 RESPONDENTS ARE CODED 1 ON THIS VARIABLE IF THEY RESIDE IN     
                 AN AREA THAT BORDERS ANOTHER E.C. COUNTRY. THEY ARE CODED 2    
                 IF THEY RESIDE IN AN AREA THAT IS NOT ADJACENT TO ANOTHER      
                 E.C. COUNTRY. IN BELGIUM, THE NETHERLANDS, LUXEMBOURG,         
                 DENMARK, THE UNITED KINGDOM AND GREECE, REGION (VARIABLE       
                 721) IS THE CRITERION FOR DETERMINING ADJACENCY; IN FRANCE,    
                 GERMANY, ITALY, IRELAND, SPAIN, PORTUGAL, PROVINCE (VARIABLE   
                 722) IS USED AS THE CRITERION.>                                
                                                                                
                     1.  FRONTIER ZONE <ADJACENT TO ANOTHER E.C. COUNTRY>       
                     2.  NON-FRONTIER ZONE <NOT ADJACENT TO ANOTHER E.C.        
                         COUNTRY>

                 ORIGINAL RESPONDENT IDENTIFICATION NUMBER                      
                 -----------------------------------------                      
                                                                                
                 <THIS IS THE ORIGINAL RESPONDENT IDENTIFICATION NUMBER         
                 SUPPLIED BY FAITS ET OPINIONS. THE FIRST TWO DIGITS IDENTIFY   
                 THE COUNTRY OF INTERVIEW (01: FRANCE; 02: GREAT BRITAIN; 03:   
                 GERMANY; 04: ITALY; 05: NETHERLANDS; 06: DENMARK; 07:          
                 BELGIUM; 08: LUXEMBOURG; 09: IRELAND; 10: NORTHERN IRELAND;    
                 11: GREECE; 12: SPAIN; 13: PORTUGAL). THE REMAINING FOUR       
                 DIGITS CONTAIN COUNTRY-SPECIFIC QUESTIONNAIRE NUMBERS.>        
                                                                                
                 <NOTE: THESE IDENTIFICATION NUMBERS ARE NOT NECESSARILY        
                 UNIQUE. MANY DUPLICATES HAVE BEEN DETECTED IN THE DATA.>       
                                                                                
                 ACTUAL NUMBER IS CODED.

-                                          APPENDIX                             
0                                                                               
0                                      *** NOTE   1 ***                         
                                    RESPONSES TO Q.123/124.                     
0                                                                               
                 <ANSWERS TO THE OPEN-ENDED QUESTION 123/124 WERE CATEGORIZED   
                 DIFFERENTLY IN EACH COUNTRY. IN ALL, THERE ARE 13 DIFFERENT    
                 CLASSIFICATION SCHEMES, EACH COMPRISING FROM 12 TO 36          
                 RESPONSE CATEGORIES.                                           
                                                                                
                 RESPONSE CATEGORIES ARE REPRESENTED IN THE DATA BY A SERIES    
                 OF 36 VARIABLES, Q.123/124(1) THROUGH Q.123/124(36). THESE     
                 VARIABLES ARE DESIGNATED BY THEIR QUESTION NUMBER AND A        
                 PARENTHESIZED SUFFIX WHICH IDENTIFIES EACH RESPONSE CATEGORY   
                 BY ITS CATEGORY NUMBER. FOR EXAMPLE, Q.123/124(6) REPRESENTS   
                 CATEGORY NUMBER 6, I.E., "AIDS, HEALTH" FOR FRENCH             
                 RESPONDENTS, "ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL SITUATION IN BELGIUM"     
                 FOR BELGIAN RESPONDENTS, AND SO ON.                            
                                                                                
                 Q.123/124(1) THROUGH Q.123/124(36) ARE CODED 1, 0 OR 9:        
                                                                                
                 CODE 1: IF A RESPONDENT'S ANSWER WAS CLASSIFIED AS A           
                 RESPONSE OF THE CATEGORY REPRESENTED BY A GIVEN VARIABLE,      
                 THEN THAT VARIABLE IS CODED 1.                                 
                                                                                
                 CODE 0: IF A RESPONDENT'S ANSWER WAS NOT CLASSIFIED AS A       
                 RESPONSE OF THE CATEGORY REPRESENTED BY A GIVEN VARIABLE,      
                 THEN THAT VARIABLE IS CODED 0.                                 
                                                                                
                 CODE 9: THIS CODE FLAGS INAPPLICABLE CATEGORIES IF A           
                 CATEGORY NUMBER (1-36) IS NOT USED WITHIN A GIVEN              
                 CLASSIFICATION SCHEME BECAUSE THE SCHEME HAS LESS THAN 36      
                 CATEGORIES, THEN THE VARIABLE REPRESENTING THE UNUSED          
                 CATEGORY IS INAPPLICABLE FOR THE COUNTRY IN QUESTION AND IS    
                 CODED 9 FOR ALL RESPONDENTS WHO WERE INTERVIEWED THERE.        
                                                                                
                 CLASSIFICATION SCHEMES FOR EACH COUNTRY ARE SHOWN BELOW.>      
0

0                                      *** NOTE   2 ***                         
                                                                                
                                    RESPONSES TO Q.173/174.                     
0                                                                               
                 <ANSWERS TO THE OPEN-ENDED QUESTION Q.173/174 WERE             
                 CLASSIFIED INTO 16 RESPONSE CATEGORIES COMMON TO ALL           
                 COUNTRIES, PLUS ADDITIONAL COUNTRY-SPECIFIC RESPONSE           
                 CATEGORIES. THE RESPONSE CATEGORIES COMMON TO ALL COUNTRIES    
                 ARE DUBBED THE "COMMON CODES" AND ARE ASSIGNED CATEGORY        
                 NUMBERS 1 THROUGH 13 AND 22 THROUGH 24. COUNTRY-SPECIFIC       
                 RESPONSE CATEGORIES ARE ASSIGNED CATEGORY NUMBERS 14 THROUGH   
                 21. THE CLASSIFICATION SCHEMES FOR BELGIUM, GERMANY, SPAIN,    
                 FRANCE, IRELAND AND LUXEMBOURG COMPRISE THE COMMON CODES       
                 ONLY. CLASSIFICATION SCHEMES FOR NORTHERN IRELAND, GREAT       
                 BRITAIN AND THE REMAINING COUNTRIES ALSO INCLUDE FROM ONE TO   
                 SEVEN COUNTRY-SPECIFIC RESPONSE CATEGORIES.                    
                                                                                
                 RESPONSE CATEGORIES ARE REPRESENTED IN THE DATA BY A SERIES    
                 OF 24 VARIABLES, Q.173/174(1) THROUGH Q.173/174(24). THESE     
                 VARIABLES ARE DESIGNATED BY THEIR QUESTION NUMBER AND A        
                 PARENTHESIZED SUFFIX WHICH IDENTIFIES EACH RESPONSE CATEGORY   
                 BY ITS CATEGORY NUMBER. FOR EXAMPLE, Q.173/174(9) REPRESENTS   
                 CATEGORY NUMBER 9, I.E., "TURKS."                              
                                                                                
                 Q.173/174(1) THROUGH Q.173/174(36) ARE CODED 1, 0 OR 9.        
                                                                                
                 CODE 1: IF A RESPONDENT'S ANSWER WAS CLASSIFIED AS A           
                 RESPONSE OF THE CATEGORY REPRESENTED BY A GIVEN VARIABLE,      
                 THEN THAT VARIABLE IS CODED 1.                                 
                                                                                
                 CODE 0: IF A RESPONDENT'S ANSWER WAS NOT CLASSIFIED AS A       
                 RESPONSE OF THE CATEGORY REPRESENTED BY A GIVEN VARIABLE,      
                 THEN THAT VARIABLE IS CODED 0.                                 
                                                                                
                 CODE 9: THIS CODE FLAGS INAPPLICABLE CATEGORIES.               
                 CLASSIFICATION SCHEMES FOR THIS QUESTION CONTAIN NO MORE       
                 THAN 23 RESPONSE CATEGORIES APIECE. THUS, FOR EVERY COUNTRY,   
                 AT LEAST ONE OF THE EIGHT VARIABLES RESERVED FOR THE           
                 COUNTRY-SPECIFIC CATEGORIES -- Q.173/174(14) THROUGH           
                 Q.173/174(21) -- DOES NOT REPRESENT ANY RESPONSE CATEGORY.     
                 VARIABLES CORRESPONDING TO CATEGORY NUMBERS THAT ARE NOT       
                 USED WITHIN A GIVEN CLASSIFICATION SCHEME ARE INAPPLICABLE     
                 FOR THE COUNTRY IN QUESTION AND ARE CODED 9 FOR ALL            
                 RESPONDENTS WHO WERE INTERVIEWED THERE.                        
                                                                                
                 CLASSIFICATION SCHEMES FOR EACH COUNTRY ARE SHOWN BELOW.       
                 DESCRIPTIONS OF COMMON CODES CATEGORIES ALSO APPEAR WITHIN     
                 THE MAIN BODY OF THE CODEBOOK.>                                
0                                                                               
                                                                                
1             632

0                                      *** NOTE   3 ***                         
                                                                                
                                      RESPONSES TO Q.175.                       
0                                                                               
                 <ANSWERS TO THE OPEN-ENDED QUESTION Q.175 WERE CLASSIFIED      
                 INTO SEVEN RESPONSE CATEGORIES COMMON TO ALL COUNTRIES, PLUS   
                 ADDITIONAL COUNTRY-SPECIFIC CATEGORIES. THE RESPONSE           
                 CATEGORIES COMMON TO ALL COUNTRIES ARE DUBBED THE "COMMON      
                 CODES" AND ARE ASSIGNED CATEGORY NUMBERS 1, 2, 6, 7, 8, 10     
                 AND 11. COUNTRY-SPECIFIC RESPONSE CATEGORIES ARE ASSIGNED      
                 CATEGORY NUMBERS 3, 4, 5, 9 AND 12. EACH CLASSIFICATION        
                 SCHEME COMPRISES THE COMMON CODES AND FOUR OR FIVE             
                 COUNTRY-SPECIFIC CATEGORIES.                                   
                                                                                
                 RESPONSE CATEGORIES ARE REPRESENTED IN THE DATA BY A SERIES    
                 OF 12 VARIABLES, Q.175(1) THROUGH Q.175(12). THESE VARIABLES   
                 ARE DESIGNATED BY THEIR QUESTION NUMBER AND A PARENTHESIZED    
                 SUFFIX WHICH IDENTIFIES EACH RESPONSE CATEGORY BY ITS          
                 CATEGORY NUMBER. FOR EXAMPLE, Q.175(6) REPRESENTS RESPONSE     
                 CATEGORY NUMBER 6, I.E., "TURKS."                              
                                                                                
                 Q.175(1) THROUGH Q.175(12) ARE CODED 1, 0 OR 9:                
                                                                                
                 CODE 1: IF A RESPONDENT'S ANSWER WAS CLASSIFIED AS A           
                 RESPONSE OF THE CATEGORY REPRESENTED BY A GIVEN VARIABLE,      
                 THEN THAT VARIABLE IS CODED 1.                                 
                                                                                
                 CODE 0: IF A RESPONDENT'S ANSWER WAS NOT CLASSIFIED AS A       
                 RESPONSE OF THE CATEGORY REPRESENTED BY A GIVEN VARIABLE,      
                 THEN THAT VARIABLE IS CODED 0.                                 
                                                                                
                 CODE 9: THIS CODE FLAGS INAPPLICABLE CATEGORIES. THE           
                 CLASSIFICATION SCHEMES FOR FRANCE, BELGIUM, ITALY              
                 LUXEMBOURG, IRELAND, GREECE AND SPAIN INCLUDE ONLY 11          
                 CATEGORIES NUMBERED FROM 1 TO 11. CONSEQUENTLY, Q.175(12) IS   
                 INAPPLICABLE FOR THESE COUNTRIES AND IS CODED 9 FOR ALL        
                 RESPONDENTS WHO WERE INTERVIEWED THERE.                        
                                                                                
                 CLASSIFICATION SCHEMES FOR EACH COUNTRY ARE SHOWN BELOW.       
                 DESCRIPTIONS OF THE COMMON CODES CATEGORIES ALSO APPEAR        
                 WITHIN THE MAIN BODY OF THE CODEBOOK.>                         
0

                                      RESPONSES TO Q.176.                       
0                                                                               
                 <ANSWERS TO THE OPEN-ENDED QUESTION Q.176 WERE CLASSIFIED      
                 INTO EIGHT RESPONSE CATEGORIES COMMON TO ALL COUNTRIES, PLUS   
                 ADDITIONAL COUNTRY-SPECIFIC CATEGORIES. THE RESPONSE           
                 CATEGORIES COMMON TO ALL COUNTRIES ARE DUBBED THE "COMMON      
                 CODES" AND ARE ASSIGNED CATEGORY NUMBERS 1, 4, 5 AND 7         
                 THROUGH 11. COUNTRY-SPECIFIC RESPONSE CATEGORIES ARE           
                 ASSIGNED CATEGORY NUMBERS 2, 3, 6 AND 12. THE CLASSIFICATION   
                 SCHEMES OF NORTHERN IRELAND, GREAT BRITAIN AND THE OTHER       
                 E.C. COUNTRIES EACH COMPRISE THE COMMON CODES AND 4            
                 COUNTRY-SPECIFIC RESPONSE CATEGORIES.                          
                                                                                
                 RESPONSE CATEGORIES ARE REPRESENTED IN THE DATA BY A SERIES    
                 OF 12 VARIABLES, Q.176(1) TO Q.176(12). THESE VARIABLES ARE    
                 DESIGNATED BY THEIR QUESTION NUMBER AND A PARENTHESIZED        
                 SUFFIX WHICH IDENTIFIES EACH RESPONSE CATEGORY BY ITS          
                 CATEGORY NUMBER. FOR EXAMPLE, Q.176(7) REPRESENTS RESPONSE     
                 CATEGORY NUMBER 7, I.E. "BUDDHISTS."                           
                                                                                
                 Q.176(1) THROUGH Q.176(12) TAKEN ON VALUES OF 1 AND 0 ONLY.    
                 IF A RESPONDENT'S ANSWER WAS CLASSIFIED AS A RESPONSE OF THE   
                 CATEGORY REPRESENTED BY A GIVEN VARIABLE, THEN THAT VARIABLE   
                 IS CODED 1. OTHERWISE, IT IS CODED 0.                          
                                                                                
                 CLASSIFICATION SCHEMES FOR EACH COUNTRY ARE SHOWN BELOW.       
                 DESCRIPTIONS OF COMMON CODES CATEGORIES ALSO APPEAR WITHIN     
                 THE MAIN BODY OF THE CODEBOOK.>

                                    RESPONSES TO Q.177/178.                     
0                                                                               
                 <ANSWERS TO THE OPEN-ENDED QUESTION Q.177/178 WERE             
                 CLASSIFIED INTO 22 RESPONSE CATEGORIES COMMON TO ALL           
                 COUNTRIES, PLUS ADDITIONAL COUNTRY-SPECIFIC CATEGORIES. THE    
                 RESPONSE CATEGORIES COMMON TO ALL COUNTRIES ARE DUBBED THE     
                 "COMMON CODES" AND ARE ASSIGNED CATEGORY NUMBERS 1 THROUGH 3   
                 AND 5 THROUGH 23. COUNTRY-SPECIFIC CATEGORIES ARE ASSIGNED     
                 CATEGORY NUMBERS 4 AND 24.                                     
                                                                                
                 RESPONSE CATEGORIES ARE REPRESENTED IN THE DATA BY A SERIES    
                 OF 24 VARIABLES, Q.177/178(1) THROUGH Q.177/178(24). THESE     
                 VARIABLES ARE DESIGNATED BY THEIR QUESTION NUMBER AND A        
                 PARENTHESIZED SUFFIX WHICH IDENTIFIES EACH RESPONSE CATEGORY   
                 BY ITS CATEGORY NUMBER. FOR EXAMPLE, Q.177/178(6) REPRESENTS   
                 RESPONSE CATEGORY NUMBER 6, I.E., "ASIANS FROM THE FAR         
                 EAST."                                                         
                                                                                
                 Q.177/178(1) THROUGH Q.177/178(36) ARE CODED 1, 0 OR 9:        
                                                                                
                 CODE 1: IF A RESPONDENT'S ANSWER WAS CLASSIFIED AS A           
                 RESPONSE OF THE CATEGORY REPRESENTED BY A GIVEN VARIABLE,      
                 THEN THAT VARIABLE IS CODED 1.                                 
                                                                                
                 CODE 0: IF A RESPONDENT'S ANSWER WAS NOT CLASSIFIED AS A       
                 RESPONSE OF THE CATEGORY REPRESENTED BY A GIVEN VARIABLE,      
                 THEN THAT VARIABLE IS CODED 0.                                 
                                                                                
                 CODE 9: THIS CODE FLAGS INAPPLICABLE RESPONSE CATEGORIES.      
                 THE CLASSIFICATION SCHEMES FOR FRANCE, GERMANY, ITALY,         
                 LUXEMBOURG, IRELAND, NORTH IRELAND AND SPAIN CONTAIN ONLY 23   
                 RESPONSE CATEGORIES NUMBERED FROM 1 TO 23. CONSEQUENTLY,       
                 Q.177/178(24) IS INAPPLICABLE FOR THESE COUNTRIES AND IS       
                 CODED 9 FOR ALL RESPONDENTS WHO WERE INTERVIEWED THERE.        
                                                                                
                 CLASSIFICATION SCHEMES FOR EACH COUNTRY ARE SHOWN BELOW.       
                 DESCRIPTIONS OF THE COMMON CODES CATEGORIES ALSO APPEAR        
                 WITHIN THE MAIN BODY OF THE CODEBOOK.>
